senses.definition: the system of using twenty-four numbers to talk about the hours of the day, instead of dividing it into two units of twelve hours
the period of the year during which students go to school or university

examples.x: The students return in October for the start of the new academic year.

senses.definition: used in the Christian calendar to show a particular number of years since the year when Christ was believed to have been born (from Latin ‘Anno Domini’) leap year

examples.x: in (the year) AD 55
in 55 AD
in the fifth century AD

senses.definition: an extremely long period of time; thousands of years

examples.x: Only yesterday—and it seemed aeons ago, not just a few hours—he had been a happily married man.

senses.definition: a major division of time, divided into eras

examples.x: aeons of geological history
These hills have been worn down over aeons of geological time.

senses.definition: later than something; following something in time

examples.x: We'll leave after lunch.
They arrived shortly after 5.
Not long after that he resigned.
Let’s meet the day after tomorrow/the week after next.
After winning the prize she became famous overnight.
After an hour I went home (= when an hour had passed).
It’s ten after seven in the morning (= 7.10 a.m.).

senses.definition: next to and following somebody/something in order or importance

examples.x: Your name comes after mine in the list.
He's the tallest, after Richard.
After you (= Please go first).
After you with the charger (= Can I have it next?).

senses.definition: behind somebody when they have left; following somebody

examples.x: Shut the door after you.
I'm always having to clean up after the children (= clean the place after they have left it dirty and untidy).
He ran after her with the book.
She was left staring after him.

senses.definition: in contrast to something

examples.x: It was pleasantly cool in the house after the sticky heat outside.

senses.definition: as a result of or because of something that has happened

examples.x: I'll never forgive them after what they did.

senses.definition: despite something; although something has happened

examples.x: I can't believe she'd do that, not after all I've done for her.

senses.definition: used to show that something happens many times or continuously

examples.x: day after day of hot weather
I've told you time after time not to do that.

senses.definition: trying to find or catch somebody/something

examples.x: The police are after them.
He's after a job at our place.

senses.definition: about somebody/something

examples.x: She asked after you (= how you were).

senses.definition: in the style of somebody/something; following the example of somebody/something

examples.x: a painting after Goya
We named the baby Ena after her grandmother.

senses.definition: happening or done later than the time or event mentioned

examples.x: after-hours drinking (= after closing time)
an after-school club
after-dinner mints

senses.definition: the period of time from 12 o'clock in the middle of the day until about 6 o’clock in the evening

examples.x: this/yesterday/tomorrow afternoon
In the afternoon, they went shopping.
Where were you on the afternoon of May 21?
Heavy snow arrived during the afternoon.
She studies art two afternoons a week.
Come over on Sunday afternoon.
The baby always has an afternoon nap.
Are you ready for this afternoon's meeting?
The activities are split into morning and afternoon sessions.

senses.definition: during the afternoon every day

examples.x: Afternoons he works at home.

senses.definition: at a later time; after an event that has already been mentioned -ward

examples.x: Afterwards she was sorry for what she'd said.
Let's go out now and eat afterwards.
Shortly afterwards he met her again.
He went to dinner at a restaurant, and soon afterwards, he fell ill.

senses.definition: the number of years that a person has lived or a thing has existed

examples.x: You're the same age as my brother.
ways of calculating the age of the earth
to reach retirement age
He left school at the age of 18.
He started playing the piano at an early age.
At your age I had already started work.
Children can start school from the age of four.
children between the ages of 5 and 10

The children's ages range from 5 to 10.
Children over the age of 12 must pay full fare.
The film is unsuitable for children below 12 years of age.
Young people of all ages go there to meet.
She needs more friends of her own age.
All ages admitted.
He was tall for his age (= taller than you would expect, considering his age).
She was beginning to feel her age (= feel that she was getting old).
The show appeals to all age ranges.
There’s a big age gap between them (= a big difference in their ages).

senses.definition: a very long time

examples.x: It'll probably take ages to find a parking space.
I waited for ages.
Carlos left ages ago.
It's been an age since we've seen them.

senses.definition: a particular period of a person’s life be born and raised/​bred

examples.x: in middle/old age
15 is an awkward age.

senses.definition: a particular period of history

examples.x: the nuclear age
We live in an age of globalization.
a study of fashion through the ages

senses.definition: the state of being old

examples.x: The jacket was showing signs of age.
White hair is a sign of great age.
Wine improves with age.
the wisdom that comes with age

senses.definition: a length of time that is a division of an epoch
used in expressions of time with the simple past tense to show how far in the past something happened ago

examples.x: two weeks/months/years ago
The letter came a few days ago.
She was here just a minute ago.
a short/long time ago
How long ago did you buy it?
It was on TV not (so) long ago.
Scientists think there was water on Mars a long time ago.
He stopped working some time ago (= quite a long time ago).
They're getting married? It's not that long ago (= it's only a short time ago) that they met!

senses.definition: used in the Muslim calendar to show a particular number of years since the year when Muhammad left Mecca in AD 622 (from Latin ‘Anno Hegirae’)

examples.x: a Koran dated 556 AH

senses.definition: further forward in space or time than somebody/something; in front of somebody/something

examples.x: Two boys were ahead of us.
Ahead of us lay ten days of intensive training.

senses.definition: earlier than somebody/something

examples.x: I finished several days ahead of the deadline.

senses.definition: further advanced than somebody/something; in front of somebody, for example in a race or competition

examples.x: She was always well ahead of the rest of the class.
His ideas were way ahead of their time (= very new and so not widely understood or accepted).

senses.definition: what is measured in minutes, hours, days, etc.

examples.x: The world exists in time and space.
The changing seasons mark the passage of time.

Perceptions change over time (= as time passes).

The main character is able to travel through time.

senses.definition: the time shown on a clock in minutes and hours

examples.x: What time is it/What’s the time?
Do you have the time?
What time do you make it?
What time do you have?

senses.definition: the time measured in a particular part of the world

examples.x: 6 o’clock local time

senses.definition: on the day before today day

examples.x: A company spokeswoman said yesterday that no final decision had been made yet.
yesterday morning/afternoon/evening
The company yesterday announced a $40 million deal.
To think I was lying on a beach only the day before yesterday.
I can remember our wedding as if it were yesterday.
They arrived yesterday.
Where were you yesterday morning?
Figures released yesterday show 4,944 people were awaiting surgery.

senses.definition: the day before today

examples.x: Yesterday was Sunday.
What happened at yesterday's meeting?

She died in the early hours of yesterday.
He threatened to resign from the coalition if no agreement was reached by yesterday.

senses.definition: the recent past

examples.x: Yesterday's students are today's employees.
All her yesterdays had vanished without a trace.

senses.definition: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen Already

examples.x: I haven't received a letter from him yet.
I didn't receive a letter from him yet.
‘Are you ready?’ ‘No, not yet.’
We don't yet know what really happened.
We have yet to decide what action to take (= We have not decided what action to take).

senses.definition: now; as soon as this

examples.x: Don't go yet.
We don't need to start yet.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens

examples.x: snow, snow and yet more snow
yet another diet book
Prices were cut yet again (= once more, after many other times).

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then

examples.x: the most comprehensive study yet of his music
It was the tallest building yet constructed anywhere.

senses.definition: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed

examples.x: He'll be busy for ages yet.
They won't arrive for at least two hours yet.

senses.definition: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely

examples.x: We may win yet.
She could yet surprise us all.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something (= how bad, important, etc. it is)

examples.x: a recent and yet more improbable theory

senses.definition: a long time donkey

examples.x: I haven't seen you for yonks!
